name: 9,10-anthracenedione, 1,4-dimethyl-
Reason: The basic unit for this compound is anthracene, which has a melting point of about 216 °C. The addition of the quinone structure (dione) with the two carbonyl groups traditionally lowers the melting point due to the rigid planar structure and the disruption of the perfect stacking in anthracene crystals. This effect can be estimated to decrease the melting point by approximately -75 °C. Two methyl groups are present on the aromatic ring, which generally increase the melting point due to an increase in molecular weight and van der Waals interactions. The addition of a methyl group to an aromatic system such as anthracene could be estimated to increase the melting point by approximately +5 °C per group. Therefore, the overall prediction would be 216 - 75 + (2 x 5) = 151 °C.

name: 9,10-anthracenedione, 1,4-dimethyl-
Reason: The basic unit for this compound is anthracene, which has a melting point of about 216 °C. The quinone groups typically lower the melting point due to less efficient stacking compared to the perfect crystalline structure of anthracene, an effect estimated to decrease the melting point by approximately -75 °C. Each of the two methyl groups adds to the melting point by creating more van der Waals forces due to added bulk, which can be estimated at about +2.75 °C per group. Therefore, the calculation would be 216 - 75 + (2 x 2.75) = 146.5 °C.
